turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Kastle–Meyer test.
turn.1: What is the expected outcome of the Kastle–Meyer test?
turn.2: Upon reduction, the very intense pink color of the cationic form of phenolphthalein fades to a faint yellow color.
turn.3: Do you have any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: It is this form of phenolphthalein that is present in Kastle–Meyer test kits.
turn.6: In order to generate the intense pink color indicative of a positive test, the reduced phenolphthalein must be oxidized back to its normal, colored form.
turn.7: Is there anything else that can be done for a positive result?
turn.8: In the relevant reaction, hydrogen peroxide reacts with the hemoglobin in the blood.
turn.9: What else can you tell me about a positive result?
turn.10: Phenolphthalin does not directly participate in this process; instead, it acts as an external source of electrons.
turn.11: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.12: In its reaction with hydrogen peroxide, the heme center of hemoglobin behaves as a peroxidase, reducing the peroxide to water.
